articles.author: Christina Farr
articles.title: Couples are nervous about their weddings and honeymoons as the coronavirus continues to spread
articles.description: It's love in the time of the coronavirus.
articles.content:
Emily Webb and Kevin Beach
Emily Webb and her fiance Kevin Beach are getting married in San Diego in early April. Many of their guests for the 200-person wedding are based locally, but a few dozen of them are planning to fly in from across the country.
For … [+5583 chars]

articles.author: Emma Newburger
articles.title: Plummeting oil prices and mortgage rates could boost consumers despite coronavirus fears
articles.description: Analysts argue that a continued decline in oil prices and mortgage rates amid the coronavirus outbreak will give the consumer a boost that could help delay a possible recession.
articles.content: As the deadly coronavirus spreads across the globe, oil prices are down 30% for the year and the average rate on the popular 30-year fixed mortgage has fallen to an 8-year low. It's positive news for consumers in the short term, even as some economists warn t… [+3095 chars]

articles.author: Pippa Stevens
articles.title: Oil is now a 'bigger problem for markets than the coronavirus,' analyst says
articles.description: As oil prices plummet deeper into bear market territory, the repercussions could be felt throughout the U.S. economy.
articles.content:
Oil prices plunged last week as OPEC and its allies failed to reach an agreement on production cuts, and as prices look set to continue cratering, some are warning about the impact on the broader economy.
"Crude has become a bigger problem for markets than t… [+3344 chars]

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.title: Virus-hit cruise ship off California's coast will dock in Oakland
articles.content:
A cruise ship that was hit by the new coronavirus is headed to the port of Oakland, California, the captain told passengers Saturday night.

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.title: Italy announces quarantine affecting quarter of population
articles.description: Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte signed a decree after midnight that imposes restrictions to the movement of people in the region of Lombardy and in at least 15 provinces, home to more than 16 million people.
articles.content:
Italy's prime minister announced a sweeping coronavirus quarantine early Sunday, imposing restrictions on the movement of about a quarter of the country's population in a bid to contain a widening outbreak.

articles.author: Natasha Turak
articles.title: OPEC deal collapse sparks price war: '$20 oil in 2020 is coming'
articles.description: The news is a sudden U-turn from previous attempts to support the oil market as the new coronavirus hammers global demand.
articles.content:
Experts are calling dramatically lower crude prices as major OPEC and non-OPEC producers prepare for an all-out price war, in a sudden U-turn from previous attempts to support the oil market as the new coronavirus hammers global demand.

articles.author: Reuters
articles.title: Italy plans to lock down Milan area, nation's financial hub, in effort to contain coronavirus
articles.description: The new rules include telling people not to enter or leave Lombardy, which is home to some 10 million people, as well as 11 provinces in four of Italy's 19 other regions, according to a draft decree seen by Reuters.
articles.content:
Italy is set to impose a virtual lockdown on its wealthiest and most populous region, which includes the financial capital Milan, as part of tough new measures to try to contain the coronavirus outbreak.

articles.author: Natasha Turak
articles.title: Saudi Aramco shares fall below IPO price for first time, Gulf stocks plummet after OPEC deal failure
articles.description: Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, Dubai and Kuwait indexes were all trading significantly lower following Sunday's market open.
articles.content:
Shares of Saudi state oil giant Aramco traded below their original IPO price for the first time Sunday, at 30.90 riyals ($8.24) at 12:30 p.m. in Riyadh compared to the listing price of 32 riyals in December. That's down 6.36% on the day.

articles.author: Lauren Hirsch
articles.title: Trump is enlisting Big Pharma to stem the coronavirus crisis — and the industry hopes to win him over
articles.description: The crisis is throwing together the pharmaceutical industry and President Trump as somewhat unlikely bedfellows: The pharma industry is seeking to prove its value, while Trump is hoping it will help stop the damage.
articles.content:
As confirmed cases of the coronavirus continue to rise, President Donald Trump has quickly embraced the pharmaceutical industry he once vilified for its high prices. The industry has, in turn, jumped on the opportunity.
